reviewText: The Blue-ray versions of the Poirot 1-hr. episodes are markedly better than the DVD version in resolution and color, whether watched on a flat screen TV or via a projector. I'm glad I found the Blue-ray versions halfway through building my Poirot Series library.

The second series of Agatha Christie's "Poirot" adapts one novel and eight short stories into ten fifty-minute episodes (the novel being split into two parts) and stars David Suchet in what is considered by many to be the definitive performance of Christie's famous Belgian detective. Working as a private investigator who is often called in by Scotland Yard to help with some of their more baffling cases, Poirot enjoys a modest lifestyle amidst the Art Deco styling of 1930s England, which the show goes to great pains to reproduce. Working alongside Suchet is Hugh Fraser as his Watsonian sick-kick Captain Hastings, Philip Jackson as the by-the-books Chief Inspector Japp, and Pauline Moran as Poirot's immensely efficient secretary Miss Lemon. As a long running series that began in 1989 and only recently finished filming the final adaptations of Christie's books in 2012, the release of the older episodes on DVD is a treat for long-time fans of the show. With writers such as Clive Exton, Anthony Horowitz (best known for the Alex Rider series) and David Renwick (creator of Jonathan Creek) penning some of the screenplays, it comes as no surprise that the show has won plenty of awards, including BAFTAs in its time. Although the pacing can be a little slow by today's standards, the earliest episodes of "Poirot" still stand as the benchmark not only for faithful Christie adaptations, but mystery shows in general. "Peril at End House" is the highlight of this box-set, with higher production values and a more sophisticated story than the rest of the episodes. Spread over two parts, this is the only story that is based on one of Christie's novels rather than a short story. Poirot and Hastings take a holiday to a Cornish seaside resort where they meet the charming Nick Buckley (played by a young Polly Walker, now probably best known for playing Atia on Rome) who tells them that she's lately had a string of near-fatal accidents. Poirot's curiosity is piqued, and he warns Nick that her life is in danger, urging her to take precautions amongst her inner circle of friends. Nick laughs it off, at least until her lookalike cousin is shot dead. Now the race is on to find the killer before he's successful in his attempt to finish off Nick. The rest of the episodes are fifty-minute episodes based on short stories that can be found in various Christie/Poirot anthologies. They are as follows: "The Veiled Lady" Poirot ponders how effective he would be as a master-criminal at the same time a beautiful woman (wearing a veil for discretion) asks for his help in retrieving a compromising letter from a blackmailer who is threatening to send it to her fianc just a few days before her wedding. Poirot concludes that the only way to retrieve her property is to break into the blackmailer's house and get it himself, resulting in a scheme that ends up with Poirot on the wrong side of the law! "The Disappearance of Mr Davenheim" Mr Davenheim leaves his house to meet with a fellow businessman, but never reaches the train station. His college swears that he passed nobody in the lane on his way to the house, and his wife is at a loss to account for his disappearance. To further complicate the investigation, Inspector Japp makes a bet with Poirot: that he can't solve the mystery without leaving his apartment. "Double Sin" Surprised by news that Poirot wants to retire, it's up to Hastings to solve the mystery of missing miniatures that were stolen on their way to an American buyer. Having been on the bus during which the case containing the miniatures were taken (and befriended the young woman responsible for delivering them safely), Hastings is further astonished when he reaches the buyer to find them already in his possession. "The Adventure of the Cheap Flat" Poirot is intrigued by a young couple's tale of how they acquired their flat: not only did it come remarkably cheap, but several other applicants were turned away before the Robinsons were accepted as the new tenants. But why does the landlord say that they've lived there for six months when they only moved in a few days ago? "The Kidnapped Prime Minister" This one involves - well, exactly what the title says. Poirot is called in by the British government to track down the Prime Minister, due to make an important speech on Germany's disarmament, but who has gone missing after an assassination attempt. Government officials are on the verge of panic, but what Poirot really wants to know is why the kidnappers would want to take the Prime Minister alive after first making an attempt on his life. "The Adventure of the Western Star" Two women with matching diamond necklaces have both received threatening letters demanding the return of their diamonds to a Chinese god. Each woman's husband has their own plans for the jewels in question, and Poirot must ferret out the secrets that exist between husbands and wives if he's to uncover the mystery behind the diamonds before they're lost for good. "The Lost Mine" A map to a valuable silver mine vanishes along with the man who planned to sell it, whilst a confused young man is found lying unconscious in an alleyway next to a dead body. This one contains such rather cringe-worthy Asian stereotypes, right down to the silk-wearing prostitutes, opium dens and "Asian Speekee Engrish" caricatures. "The Cornish Mystery" A woman comes to Poirot for help, suspecting that her husband is trying to poison her. Poirot arrives at her home the following day to find that she has passed away in the night and so begins his investigation of her family and friends in the attempt to track down the killer - much to the displeasure of Japp, who considers it an open and shut case. For those interested, all of these short mysteries (except The Cornish Mystery" and "Double Sin") can be found in Poirot Investigates, an anthology of many of his cases, and of course Peril at End House is its own self-contained novel. As you can see from the summaries, the shorter episodes rarely deal with murder, instead revolving around espionage, kidnapping and theft. That and the fact that Poirot's cohorts provide some comedic relief to the proceedings means that these early episodes are far lighter in tone than later installments in the series. The problem with adapting some of these mysteries is that Christie's short stories were (obviously) very short - sometimes only a few pages long. As such, many of the episodes need to be padded out in order to fill up the running time. This results in subplots such as Poirot looking after a friend's talking parrot or Miss Lemon losing her keys and finding them two days later in the very first place she should have looked, or extended scenes such as car-chases and police stakeouts. There's never a dull moment in the feature-length "Peril at End House", but some of the shorter mysteries can drag a little. But nevertheless, this is still a superior production, and it's obvious that great care has been taken with Christie's original material, the actors' commitment to their roles, and the distinctive Art Deco style on display throughout the show's sets, locations, costuming, vehicles and general late 1920s/1930s ambiance.

David Suchet is priceless in his role of Poirot.  We enjoyed every story in the Series 2 collection.  We started watching these mysteries on PBS and had to have our own to view and review every story.  We enjoy the roles of Capt. Hastings and Miss Lemon.  We miss them in the Poirot movies.  Long live Agatha Christie's Poirot.  We recommend these DVDs for any mystery fan.

With the great success of series 1, LWT (London Weekend Television) quickly continued with an equally successful series 2.
This time, along with Agatha Christie's Poirot short stories, one Agatha Christie Poirot novel story was included, creating a double length episode. This longer story allowed for a more intriguing mystery.
The rest of the season was filled out with Poirot short stories, but the 'pilot' of the longer double episode showed that LWT was capable of producing the Poirot Novels for television.
Series 3 would dramatize another novel, and series 4 would would feature 4 novels and no short stories.

ITV, the current owners of the LWT programs, went back to the original film elements and remastered them in HD. Yes, there are subtitles.

Agatha Christie's Poirot series 2 (50 minutes unless noted)
11  2-01  07/Jan/90  Peril at End House (2-hour episode)
12  2-02  14/Jan/90  The Veiled Lady
13  2-03  21/Jan/90  The Lost Mine
14  2-04  28/Jan/90  The Cornish Mystery
15  2-05  04/Feb/90  The Disappearance of Mr. Davenheim
16  2-06  11/Feb/90  Double Sin
17  2-07  18/Feb/90  The Adventure of the Cheap Flat
18  2-08  25/Feb/90  The Kidnapped Prime Minister
19  2-09  04/Mar/90  The Adventure of the Western Star

While 16mm will never look as sharp as 35mm, if you directly transfer the original 16mm camera film elements they will always look better & sharper than the older DVDs mastered from 16mm film copies made form 16mm negatives. The camera originals are sharper than the copies.

What more can one say about Hercule Poirot?  As he states himself, he is the best and most famous detective in the world (circa 1930s).  Settings and character actors are outstanding.  David Suchet is inimitable.  I have grown fond of Detective Chief Inspector Japp, who appears in the early series.  Plot is always entertaining. My only complaint is that the British film makers still need to improve their audio recordings.  Especially when there is a heavy accent and the microphone is not well placed, it is difficult to discern exactly what is being said.  This Series provides very good value.

David Suchet - the ONLY one fit to play this character, Poirot! He is fantastic.  In this articular series of 9 episodes, 3 each on 3 disks, the second one on Disk 2, at the end, I cracked up - the expression on  his face as the story ends is classic!!! These are really good mystery's and good for the whole family!  Suchet's facial expressions says it all. I have 3 of the series so far!
Love this series.

Each mystery has a twist.  Poirot always keeps us guessing until the end!  Mysteries the whole family can enjoy.
Love, loved David Suchet as Poirot.

Peril at End House was so good I watched it again.  Perfect in every way, this two-part production was sumptuous, well acted and thoroughly enjoyable.  I actually got chills when Poirot and Hastings first approach the stone wall and wooden gate to End House... just as it was described in the book.  Polly Walker is exceptional as Nik.

The rest of the series is devoted to faithful retelling of several short stories, all wonderfully done.  Why or WHY can't the producers continue to stick with A.C.'s original stories instead of rewriting them?  This series is well worth the price.
More fine Poirot --- but no captions to ease the hearing impaired/
Again I say there is no mystery in why the popularity of this wonderful series- well done and always enjoyable
EXCELLENT-A+

We enjoyed the Poirot episodes when they came out in the 1980's. With so little to enjoy on television now, we decided to order several of our old favorites such as Poirot, Miss Marple, Cadfael, Sherlock Holmes (Jeremy Brett), and Frost. We plan to also order Morse and Are You Being Served? for some laughs. These series are tried and true. We are getting a lot of enjoyment re-watching all these excellent classics. When the grandchildren come over their first question is, "What are we going to watch tonight?" They are enjoying the episodes as much as we do.

I have watched Poirot many times on PBS and I wanted to start watching the seasons so  that I could see them all in order. This is the second set of Poirot DVD's I have purchased and I'm still loving them! My schedule is a little crazy with college and my other engagements, so when I get to have an hour or two to relax on the couch its wonderful to have a quality program with riveting storylines to watch. Poirot is one of the greatest set of detective stories of all time for a reason!

Interestingly the total file space needed to back up one of the Series 2 disks is about 9Gb. Series 1 disks required about 40Gb. I also noticed significantly less color depth in the Series 2 transfer versus Series 1. The image is with out a doubt sharper, but definitely lacks the color depth associated with Blu-ray. For that matter, so does Series 1, but to a lesser extent. Of course the limiting factors will be inherent in the source material. Series 3 suffers the same impairment as Series 2.
I love anything that is Poirot because, of course, he is the greatest detective in all the world. These DVDs do not disappoint this Poirot fan.
David Suchet is the perfect Poirot - Love watching these stories and watching the mystery unfold! Agatha Christie is the Queen of Mystery for a reason!

Years ago in high school, I was home sick from school and picked up my mother's Christie mystery, I was instantly hooked! Since then, Agatha Christie has always been my favorite mystery author.  Poirot is so clever and he knows it.
His arrogance is justified, he has earned it.
It is one thing to visualize the story as I am reading it but it is a pleasure to be able to see his facial expressions as he contemplates and deduces to his conclusions. I can't get enough Christie!
I like the characters.  I like being able to see England without travel.  The stories are full of interest and. of course, he always gets the bad one.
This was given as a Holiday gift and received warmly by the recipient. How could you go wrong with an Agatha Christie/ Poirot combination.

Overall very good content as all Agatha Christie Poirot murder mysteries are. And ofcourse Blu-Ray Clarity and brightness. The  negative side being the grains in the dark areas of the picture frame and 4:3 aspect ratio. personally I prefer the 16:9 aspect ratio.
This is a great CD. I think I have all of Poirots now.  Will order more if I see one that I don't have.
This is a great collection of Poirot like others in these new sets (1, 3, and 5). You get more for your money and its been a long time waiting for these early episodes.
David Suchet will always be remembered as the best Hercule Poriot in movies or in T.V.  And these stories are well written enough to take full advantage of his brilliance.
The Poirot's and the Miss Marples are so well done. David Suchet is right off the pages of Agatha Christie.

What a fantastic series do entertaining and wonderful the plots are do hard to guess I would recommend this to anyone who loves agatha christie stories

As for the shoping experience, the DVD arrived in a timely manner and in the condition described in the amazon ad.

After suffering for a decade with the crappy, dim, muddy transfers of the first Poirot DVDs, these crisp, sharp, lovely Blu Rays are a real treat. The stories, the performances, the design are all the same--everything you love about the show. They just look so much better here. So if you're a Poirot fanatic like my wife and me, you'll have to have these.

Suchet's Poirot is the epitome of the genre. And the productions in this series, all set in the Art Deco mode of the 1930s, are superb in every detail. Suchet is trying to do all the Agatha Christie "Poirots" and I hope he succeeds.

Agatha Christie's Poirot is a wonderful series. The expenses must have been great. Everything that you can imagine are period correct. This series keeps you guessing right up until the end who is the murderer.  I suggest buying all the CD's only if you like the first. I say this because if you like what you see in series one, you will love what you see it the rest of this wonderful production.
Very entertaining, but don't miss a minute and pay attention.  A wonderful glimpse of British life in the 20's and 30's.
Another beautifully directed and produced series of Poirot mysteries.  The production of this series is second to none and is such a wonderful change from so much of the rubbish produced today.

I save the DVD's for special nights and look forward to each episode with great anticipation.  They are well-made, wonderful views of London and the English countryside, and full of magnificent art deco sets.  All the actors are superb!  Agatha Christie would be pleased.

One of my #1 complaints about the Acorn DVDs was they did not have closed captioning which made it all but impossible for my nearly deaf wife to hear and enjoy Poirot, which we love.  Acorn must have heard my and others' complaints because these new series now have closed captioning.  The shows are top notch.  Absolutely no complaints about this series of DVDs.
When it comes to David Suchey's portrayal of Poirot combined with the nine wonderful stories on this DVD and the only thing to say is it is  absolute perfection.

Continuing the incredible work done restoring Season 1, the show really hits it's stride with better episodes here on Season 2. The audio quality has improved slightly from Season 1, I don't know if this was a decision for compression or what. I sometimes have trouble hearing so the English subtitles are just icing on the cake for me with these discs. Anyone purchasing season 1 and season 2 Blu-rays, I hope you continue purchasing to see this series released in full! and not mixed up into other box sets.
I am a big Christie fan and David does Poirot perfectly.  I will order more of his movies.

It seems that whatever Agatha Christie writes, it's entertaining. While I prefer Miss Marple (Margaret Rutherford version is best) and love Tommy and Tuppence, Poirot is fantastic and has been done with such a variety of actors that you must find at least one you like. For me, David Suchet is the best so far probably because he plays it straight as written and doesn't try to fashion it to his whims and fancies and Miss Lemon and Captain Hastings are also brilliantly done.
